newsitem.title: USA: Dollar hurting U.S. car sales - industry spokesman.
newsitem.headline: Dollar hurting U.S. car sales - industry spokesman.

text.p: A U.S. car manufacturing spokesman disagreed Tuesday with an assessment by Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor on Tuesday that the strong dollar has not affected U.S. car sales to Japan.

American Automobile Manufacturers Association president Andrew Card said a 30 percent decline in the value of the yen over the past year has put pressure on U.S. manufacturers' ability to price their products competitively with Japanese manufacturers.
Card said at a news conference that if Kantor does not believe U.S. car sales have been hurt by the yen-dollar relationship, "I think that he has missed reality for the last several months."
Kantor had told an earlier news conference that the strong dollar did not appear to be hurting U.S. car sales to Japan.
Card complained that the Bank of Japan bought dollars in August and said that central banks should intervene in currency markets only during a crisis.

"Exchange rates that find fluxuations of 30 percent in a year put tremendous pressures on various manufacturers to price their product competitively and produce their product to be priced competitively," he said.

Card said the 1995 car trade agreement with Japan was a good agreement, but complained that U.S. manufacturers were having a hard time signing up dealers associated with the big Japanese manufacturers. The United States set a goal of 200 new dealerships in Japan by the end of the year, but so far only 107, mostly indepedent dealers, have signed up.
"The agreement is a good agreement, but we want the results to reflect the fact that Japan's market is opening up," Card said.
